title: World Beard Day: Inside the secret world of a men’s barber shop |
text:
That’s according to Brisbane barber Steve Pelecas, who describes the style as the Ned Kelly look or captain’s beard.
“And what really tops it off is a long moustache with that curve on the side,” the 33-year-old owner of The Men’s Lounge Barber in Paddington says.
“It should be no longer than top of the chest because if you get past that then it’s more of an old bikie look.
“That Ned Kelly style gets the most comments and most respect in the barber shop.”
The Courier-Mail visited The Men’s Lounge on the eve of today’s World Beard Day which, according to one website, “is characterised by the happiness of all people being with their beards and with each other”.
Barber Steve Pelecas trims Zac Turschwell’s beard ahead of World Beard Day. Pics: Cleo Fraser (AAP) Source: AAP
Mr Pelecas describes his barber as a man-cave where blokes go to freshen up their look while talking about, well, blokey stuff.
The place definitely screams masculinity with loud rock music playing, antlers hanging from the wall and recycled rum bottles being used as hair spray canisters.
Beards are a “bro to bro thing” and men grow beards to compete with each other rather than to impress women, Mr Pelecas says.
Better Ned than dead. Source: AAP
Another beard of Brisbane. Source: AAP
Bartender Zac Turschwell, who yesterday got his beard trimmed for the first time since December, says he gave up shaving out of pure laziness.
“It was just an extra chore that I didn’t want to do,” the 21-year-old, who has had been sporting a beard for about five years, says.
“There’s just something about it — something to play with on my face and it makes me look older.
“If you see a beard that’s superior to yours there’s definitely an admiration there. It’s like: ‘nice beard dude, you’ve got enough testosterone to grow a beard’.”
Nothing like a well groomed beard. Source: AAP
Beards are all the rage. Source: AAP
Mr Pelecas says he transformed his business from a hairdressers to a barber shop after the men-only walk-in salons came back into fashion a few years ago, something he says has been driven by celebrities and social media.
Worldbeardday.com suggests clean-shaven folk spend today waiting on their hairy friends ensuring they “relax and partake in no jobs or chores”. (Our guess is the author has hair sprouting from his chin.)
